title: 110_hr1084
content: The Act titled "Reconstruction and Stabilization Civilian Management Act of 2008" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 outlines the findings of the Act. The Reconstruction and Stabilization Civilian Management Act of 2008 established the Office of the Coordinator for Reconstruction and Stabilization in the Department of State to lead and coordinate US civilian capacity in post-conflict situations. This mandate was reaffirmed in 2005 by the National Security Presidential Directive 44. The Office of the Coordinator for Reconstruction and Stabilization in the Department of State leads and coordinates US civilian capacity in post-conflict situations. National Security Presidential Directive 44 assigns the Secretary the lead role in developing strategies and coordinating interagency processes for reconstruction and stabilization operations. The Department of Defense issued Directive 3000.05, establishing stability operations as a core military mission that must be prepared for and supported. It provides guidance on evolving stability operations and assigns responsibilities for planning, training, and support within the Department of Defense. Directive 3000.05 by the Department of Defense establishes stability operations as a core military mission, providing guidance on planning, training, and support. In this Act, key definitions include Administrator (Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development), agency (entity in chapter 1 of title 5, United States Code), appropriate congressional committees (Committee on Foreign Affairs of the House of Representatives and the Committee on Foreign Relations of the Senate), Department (Department of State), personnel (individuals serving in certain services), and Secretary (Secretary). The term "Secretary" in this Act refers to the Secretary of State. SEC. 618 of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 authorizes assistance for reconstruction and stabilization crises. SEC. 618 of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 authorizes assistance for reconstruction and stabilization crises. If the President deems it necessary for US civilian agencies to aid in stabilizing a country in conflict, assistance can be provided under specific conditions and terms. The authority under section 618 of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 allows for the provision of funds for reconstruction and stabilization efforts in conflict-affected countries. Assistance can be provided using funds from other laws or provisions within the Act, subject to specific procedures. This authority is limited to fiscal years 2008, 2009, and 2010, with a cap of $100,000,000 per year. SEC. 5. RECONSTRUCTION AND STABILIZATION. Title I of the State Department Basic Authorities Act of 1956 is amended to include a new section titled "SEC. 62. RECONSTRUCTION AND STABILIZATION." This section allows for the provision of funds for reconstruction and stabilization efforts in conflict-affected countries, with a cap of $100,000,000 per year for fiscal years 2008, 2009, and 2010. The Office of the Coordinator for Reconstruction and Stabilization is established within the Department of State, with the Coordinator appointed by the President. The functions include monitoring in coordination with relevant bureaus and offices of the Department of State and the United States Agency for International Development. The United States Agency for International Development (USAID) assesses reconstruction and stabilization crises worldwide, cataloging non-military resources for assistance. Planning is done in conjunction with USAID. The United States Agency for International Development (USAID) collaborates on planning to address requirements like demobilization, disarmament, civil society rebuilding, policing, human rights monitoring, and public information in reconstruction and stabilization crises. Coordination with relevant agencies is essential to develop interagency contingency plans and procedures for deploying civilian personnel in such crises. Appropriate arrangements are made with agencies to carry out activities under this section and the Reconstruction and Stabilization Civilian Management Act of 2008. The Civilian Reserve Corps under the Reconstruction and Stabilization Civilian Management Act of 2008 involves identifying personnel in State, local governments, and the private sector for participation in reconstruction and stabilization activities. Training and education for civilian personnel are coordinated with other agencies involved in stabilization operations to ensure adequate preparedness. Plans for U.S. reconstruction and stabilization operations are coordinated and complementary to other reconstruction efforts. The Response Readiness Corps, established by the Secretary in consultation with relevant agencies, provides assistance in coordination with other governments and organizations for effective reconstruction and stabilization activities. Maintaining the capacity for quick deployment of evaluation teams for on-site needs assessment is a key function of the Corps. The Response Readiness Corps, established by the Secretary in consultation with relevant agencies, provides assistance in support of reconstruction and stabilization operations in conflict-affected regions. The Corps is composed of active and standby components consisting of US Government personnel, including employees of various agencies, who are recruited and trained to provide assistance as needed. Additionally, a Civilian Reserve Corps may be established by the Secretary in consultation with the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development. The Secretary may establish a Civilian Reserve Corps for reconstruction and stabilization activities, deploying members as determined by the President. The Corps should not impair the capacity of State and local governments. Authorization of appropriations is provided. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the Secretary of State to support a Response Readiness Corps and Civilian Reserve Corps. Personnel of the Department and USAID are required to utilize existing training programs within the Government. SEC. 6. AUTHORITIES RELATED TO PERSONNEL. Extension of certain foreign service benefits to individuals involved in reconstruction and stabilization activities. The Secretary or agency heads can provide benefits to personnel involved in these activities as outlined in the Foreign Service Act of 1980. Additionally, the Secretary has the authority to accept personnel details or assignments for carrying out the Act. Authorized to detail or assign personnel to the Department of State for purposes of section 62 of the State Department Basic Authorities Act of 1956. SEC. 7. RECONSTRUCTION AND STABILIZATION STRATEGY. The Secretary of State, in consultation with the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, will develop an interagency strategy for reconstruction and stabilization operations. The strategy will focus on improving skills, identifying agencies, increasing training for Federal civilian personnel, and creating a database of best practices. The interagency strategy for reconstruction and stabilization operations includes developing a database of proven practices and coordinating activities among agencies involved. Annual reports are required to be submitted to Congress. The Secretary of State must submit annual reports to Congress on the implementation of the Act, including details on establishing Response Readiness Corps and Civilian Reserve Corps, their structure, operations, coordination with other foreign assistance programs, and deployment impact. The annual report to Congress must include an assessment of the impact of the Civilian Reserve Corps deployment on domestic agencies and recommendations to enhance recruitment and retention. Anticipated costs for the development, sustainment, and deployment of the Civilian Reserve Corps should also be described. The House of Representatives passed the bill on March 5, 2008.
